review_title: Great position to contributing to helping a noble cause
pros: You can help McNair Scholars in everything, from organizing seminars to working on projects, to scheduling tutors for them. It is a great learning opportunity.
cons: No cons as such I remember.

pros: Had a great experience overall
cons: A small community and campus

job_title: Assistant Teaching PRofessor in Erie, PA
pros: Very welcoming environment, my department has been patient and supportive as I've transitioned into my role and I find the relationship with the students to be valued by a majority of faculty and staff here. Many faculty memebers seem open to improvement across the board so I've found that helpful.
cons: There is something to be said about having a tight group or community and what it does for generating new ideas and appealing to what students want AND need. Working here has led me to believe that many students don't know exactly what is out there waiting for them and having faculty who are at least semi-active in their respective fields would potentially change this for the better. The shaping of this institutions path forward will be limited by the imagination of all these professionals who have not strayed far from the region or been back in the field for some time. Only real con of working here thus far is this updating will take a great deal of time and convincing mixed with what could be years of admin planning.

pros: If hands-off is your thing, Gannon is for you. The benefits package is phenomenal.
cons: You can definitely get lost in the mix if you are not experienced with navigating the red tape of academia. Also, my raise was just 1% because we hired new DEI staff.

review_title: Would highly recommend passing on all opportunities at Gannon at the moment.
pros: Overall community is welcoming, student body is great, location is excellent.
cons: Middle leadership is pathetic at best. Everything is determined by how good of friends you are with someone, who you know & who you’re related too. Those who are willing to work hard are exploited, and those who are more interested in appearing busy and brown-nosing are rewarded.

pros: The campus community was full of wonderful people who genuinely loved their jobs and worked hard at creating a caring and inclusive environment but the athletic department was NOT run like this
cons: The athletic department is run like a sinking battleship with little trust in the people doing the day to day who want to do what’s right but don’t get the support and autonomy to do what actually needs to be done with undue pressure and interference

review_title: No longer the Gannon you knew.
pros: Great benefits. Retirement matching is some of the best I’ve seen. Students are bright, eager, and involved in their experience—making them a pleasure to work with.
cons:
Politics. Only people who are favorites get things. 
All about numbers. Gannon has lost it sense of mission, and is indistinguishable from public universities in that it only cares about reporting good numbers rather than doing good. Certain divisions are so broken that they have lose most of their employees every year, but those responsible for creating a terrible work environment are never held accountable due to strong levels of nepotism in hiring and reporting chain.

review_title: take the bad with the good
pros: The health insurance is top notch. Most co-workers are absolutely amazing and the students are far above those at other universities I've worked for in the past. Loads of holiday time off at Easter and Christmas. 100% undergraduate tuition reimbursement for employees and dependents.
cons: No recognition for a job well done, pay raises for staff (non-faculty) are not merit based. Everyone on campus gets the same thing - you'll get the same raise as a person who never comes in and on the rare occasion they show up does no work. Completely motivating. Months long annual review process for 26 cents, some years there wasn't a raise at all. Starting pay is well below industry standards and most staff on campus don't make a living wage.

review_title: A good place to start out, not a great place to stay
job_title: Administrative Staff in San Diego, CA
pros: Good benefit package (standard to higher ed), opportunities to partake in cross-departmental projects, students were pleasant to work with.
cons: Salaries lower than industry standard (even considering low cost of living in Erie).   Antiquated "hierarchical" power structure means that employees can be disciplined for making decisions, and approaches to management are often outdated and based on fear tactics.

pros: Contributed to the University, get to know more students, help to understand the program better, learn how to organize my time as well as others' time.

review_title: Interesting exposure to the insides of academia
pros: Relatively good compensation package.  Great group of students to work with.  They were motivated and dedicated.  Many of my coworkers acted as part of an effective team with whom I enjoyed great communication and camaraderie.
cons: The world of academia is far different than the corporate world.  Performance and quality metrics are absent.

pros: University has pretty good perks for graduate assistants and with the right professor you get to learn a lot by working on some pretty intriguing projects.
cons: Could not work for more than 10 hours a week as they didn’t allow students to second their studies for work.

pros:
You have access to the entire University when working on projects. Non-management staff are great people.
